posts.cooked:
We’ve had a lot of success this year implementing pathplanner for blue-side autonomous, but the same paths are not working when we’re on the Red alliance. The paths act like we’re still running on the Blue side, even though we’ve given a proper Boolean supplier to the ‘shouldFlipPath’ argument in AutoBuilder.configureHolonomic.

Here is a link to our current drive subsystem on GitHub.

We have a field widget on the ShuffleBoard that reports that the robot is following the correct path, but the robot’s actual behavior is that it runs into the Red driver wall when the Field widget shows it should be moving away from it.

We’ve checked and double-checked the PP docs and also other threads on here, but we’re not sure what is causing this.

We’ve tried inverting the X chassis speeds when we’re in autonomous mode on Red side, but that just caused the odometry to flip out. We also tried inverting the speed of the drive wheels when in auto on red side, but the same thing happened.

Anything else we could try?

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked: Are you changing your alliance in driver station.
Is the front of your robot facing the blue alliance side when you do this?
The FMS is handing us the alliance and station, and when we test we are changing it in the driver station.
It faces the alliance wall when we start, regardless of which side

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
We aren’t using Swerve, but we are using PathPlanner.

Here’s what we do:

Which is then defined as:

In this way, our code ensures that no matter how we set the robot down on the field, our gyro is reporting the field direction appropriately (Always Blue Origin).

Here’s a thread I made to sort of document our research, which had some great advice from other folks that ultimately ended with us successfully using pathplanner from both sides of the field.

link_counts.title: DriveTeam Robot placement of Robot on Field with PathFollowing

posts.cooked: You’re resetting your gyro upon creating Drivetrain.java each time. So when you switch to ref alliance and face your robot towards the red alliance wall, it thinks that that is 0 degrees instead of towards the blue alliance wall. What you should do is pass the initial angular position of the flipped autonomous and reset your gyro to that, so now facing red alliance is 180 degrees. You can choose to do that or have facing blue alliance as 180 degrees; personally our team has facing blue alliance as 180 degrees and facing red alliance as 0 degrees because most diagrams of the field have blue alliance on the left. Just make sure you update your gyro with that initial angle of the flipped path; our team does this by getting the path, flipping it, generating the trajectory, then doing trajectory.getInitialState().getDifferentialPose() and use that I believe (not differential drive train specific, we have swerve it’s just written that way). Personally our team just updates the poseEstimator by using the reset position method for a swerve drive pose estimator, as pose estimators are more accurate in the long run with apriltags, so we use its position’s rotation for robot angle. Hope this helps!

@NewtonCrosby and @CupOfJava

Thanks for the tips. We read up on field orientation and blue-side origin in the WPILib docs, and taking your suggestions into account, it looks like we need to be:

setting our gyro to the rotation of the starting pose of the auto that we choose

not resetting the gyro in the constructor of Drivetrain

inverting the driver’s controls based on which alliance we’re playing from.

We also remembered an issue we had in the early build season where we had added a 90° offset to each swerve wheel because when we pressed forward the robot drove “left” in relation to itself. After more reading we now realize that we didn’t properly understand how each input and orientation fit together; joystick, robot, and field. We had compensated for this in our PP paths by turning the orientation 90° at each waypoint. We think this is also contributing to the mismatch.

We’ll make these changes tonight, test tomorrow, and update back. Thanks!

Following up on this, we made the suggested changes in this branch and tested teleop first. When we used driver controls to rotate the robot, all the wheels turned to face inward towards the middle of the robot instead of tangent to the wheelbase circumference.

Since we were at competition, we had to revert back to a known-working branch so that we could finish out strong.

We’ll be working on this in between now and our next competition, but the plan is still to implement your suggestions and work out this little kink.
